results.title: Alternator 15
results.brief_description: With the tendency of cars to be fitted with more electrical equipment it is becoming increasingly important to fit an alternator rather than a dynamo. This film examines the advantages of an alternator and shows research, aided by computers, into the most acceptable design

results.title: Alternating current and direct current
results.creator_credit: John Durst and Frank A. Hoare
results.brief_description: An outline of the difference between alternating and direct current; why AC is in general use; how DC can be produced from AC; and the reasons why one or the other is used for particular purposes. The film also shows why high tension AC is preferable to low tension DC for transmission purposes.

results.title: Alpine ranger: Mt. Buffalo National Park
results.brief_description: The Mount Buffalo National Park, north-eastern Victoria, throughout the year, showing visitors skiing, bush walking, climbing and fishing and the work of a park ranger in maintenance, supervision and fire control. No other credits available.

results.title: Alphabet
results.creator_credit: Eliot Noyes, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An amusing and energetic romp through the letters of the alphabet, wittily animated by Elliot Noyes Junior. Each letter has its own objects, animals or actions to suggest words it begins - A for Apple, Z for Zebra. None, however, retains the expected form for long, fading, changing at the artist’s whimsy. For anyone at the reading-readiness stage, young or old, this is a language film to sharpen words and humour.

results.title: Alpha Omega = Alfa Omega
results.brief_description: A satirical cartoon describing the life of a typical modern man from childhood to old age, in six epochs. Between each epoch the individual has to wind himself up enough to see himself through the next phase of his life, but eventually the human “spring” can take no more. No commentary is used, simple music sets the scene.

results.title: Along the track in Central Australia
results.brief_description: Filmed in 1952 by Phillip Crosbie Morrison and the commentary edited from his recorded talks describing a tour with the Royal Australian Ornithologists’ Union, visiting Hermannsburg, Palm Valley, Ayers Rock and Mount Olga. Gives a broad view of the environment as a whole, emphasising the natural beauty and variety of the region and its wild life and showing that although arid it is not all desert.

results.title: Along the power lines
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The story of electrical power in Victoria from generating stations to consumer. Shows the prompt action taken with mobile radio-controlled teams, when break downs in supply are reported; causes of breakdowns such as lightning. Power generated from power stations at Eildon- Rubicon, the Snowy Mountains, and the Latrobe Valley is directed by engineers at the main control centre near Melbourne to main terminal stations, and on to the consumer. Electricity is distributed at high voltage over long distances, this means danger but skilled linesmen trained in safe techniques patrol existing lines and erect new ones supplying over 90 per cent of Victoria’s industrial power.

results.title: Along the beach
results.creator_credit: Arthur Cantrill, Corinne Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: This film has no dialogue, however it’s evocative soundtrack and beautiful visuals are extremely touching. A young boy runs along the beach on Stradbroke Island off Queensland, absorbed by the shimmering, rhythmic waves, and the textures, shadows and patterns of all he sees on the sand - the footprints of tiny creatures, the undulating sand shapes sculptured by the ocean currents, the shells and seaweed and the shadowy fish trapped in a pool. Music: Nancy Tow. No other credits available.

results.title: Almost everyone does
results.creator_credit: Gene Feldman and Wombat Productions, Inc.
results.brief_description: Scenes from an average middle-class family illustrate what they do to unwind- martinis, smoking, chatting, pills. The film asks, “When does a drug that changes the way a person feels become harmful or dangerous?”. Emphasises that all people have good and bad feelings, and suggests how people learn to cope with them. Explores alternatives to coping with bad feelings without recourse to drugs.
